caption.paragraph:
Figs. 4a-h.
Isoperla adunca
nymph and ventral maxilla, Campbell Creek, Butte County, CA. Submarginal setae groups A and B, Marginal setae C, and Ventral surface setae D. White bars = 1 mm, 4e-f 100x, 4g 200x, and 4h 400x.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The lacinia of male
I. adunca
larvae are distinctive in that the entire submarginal row (A+B) is continuous from the base of the apical tooth continuing to almost the inner lacinia margin ( Figs. 4 g-h). Larvae lack distinct pigment patterns, especially longitudinal abdominal stripes. The lacinia of immature larvae are also distinct and resemble mature larvae, except that submarginal row (A+B) setae are more widely spaced.

Remarks.
Isoperla adunca
inhabits mostly nonperennial and a few perennial foothill streams of the central Sierra Nevada range. It co-occurred with the following species:
I. acula
,
I. marmorata
,
I. miwok
, and
Isoperla mormona Banks
and emergence occurred in April–June.
